docs.lead_paragraph: Insurance companies, hospitals and a consumer group joined forces today and offered a proposal to provide health insurance to about half of the 42.6 million Americans who have no coverage. The proposal was made by the Health Insurance Association of America, the American Hospital Association and the consumer group Families USA.

headline.main: Ex-Enemies On Insurance Offer a Plan

docs.abstract: Health Insurance Assn of America, American Hospital Assn and consumer group Families USA offer proposal to provide health insurance to about half of 42.6 million Americans who have no coverage; call for federal tax credits and expansion of Medicaid and new Children's Health Insurance Program to help people with incomes up to twice poverty level; proposals detailed (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Israel Retaliates in Gaza After School Bus Bombing Violence erupted in the Gaza Strip when a powerful roadside bomb ripped apart a school bus filled with Israeli pupils, instantly killing two adults and dismembering several children. In response, Israel bombarded military, police and media targets throughout Gaza. A1 Israel published a detailed catalog of what it contends is a systematic Palestinian flouting of commitments under successive peace pacts and cease-fire accords. A12

docs.lead_paragraph: Stocks Fall on Concern About Profits and Election Stock prices fell, pulled down by worries about fourth-quarter earnings, ratings downgrades by research analysts and the unresolved race for the presidency. Technology stocks were particularly weak, and the Nasdaq composite index fell to its lowest level since Oct. 28, 1999. The technology-heavy Nasdaq lost 151.55 points, or 5 percent, to 2,875.64. So far this year, the Nasdaq is down 29.3 percent. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 167.22 points, or 1.6 percent, to 10,462.65, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 25.10 points, or 1.8 percent, to 1,342.62. [Page C14.]

docs.lead_paragraph: In 15 minutes, Dr. Jiang Lijuan broke up the dense cataract that had long covered Liang Xingwang's eye, removed the debris and slipped a new tiny plastic lens under his cornea. She squirted in a few drops of antibiotic and prepared a heavy gauze bandage. Before the gauze was applied, Mr. Liang caught a fleeting glimpse of the operating room light, his first glimpse of anything from his right eye in years. ''I think I could see things!'' Mr. Liang, 17, said with wonderment as he moved to a bed in an adjoining room.

headline.main: Shunyi Journal; Blinded by Poverty: The Dark Side of Capitalism

docs.abstract: Medical care in China, which 20 years ago boasted broadest public health system in world that offered free health care to all, has become almost entirely matter of cash from individual patients, and there is no public health insurance for poor; country's shift to market economy has upset balance, allowing entry of more advanced medical techniques but also making even simple procedures widely unaffordable; World Health Organization currently rates China last among developing countries in terms of equal access to medical care; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton today issued new rules that define the rights of more than 130 million Americans to obtain prompt, fair decisions on health insurance claims and to appeal if the claims are denied or delayed. The rules will require most private employer-sponsored health plans to change their procedures for handling claims.

headline.main: New Insurance Rules for Patients Ease Way for Faster Decisions and Appeals

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton issues new rules that define rights of more than 130 million Americans to obtain prompt, fair decisions on health insurance claims and to appeal if claims are denied or delayed; rules will require most private employer-sponsored health plans to change procedures for handling claims; managed care industry spokeswoman Karen M Ignagni says new rules could encourage litigation and result result in 'litigation bonanza' for plaintiffs' lawyers; provisions of new rules discussed; Labor Sec Alexis Herman comments; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It was spaghetti sauce from a jar and canned corn for dinner. Mom had to go back to work in a few hours and there wasn't time for anything fresh. Jill Pages smoked two cigarettes, careful not to smear her makeup. The rouge, the black strokes across her eyelids and the hair piled high gave her the look of a small, wild cat.

headline.main: Average Family Just Getting By, No Safety Net; They Fly Through the Air, Usually With Greatest of Ease

docs.abstract: Profile of Pages family of trapeze artists, mother, father and two children who perform with Big Apple Circus, which is performing in New York City through January; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Clinton administration will soon issue sweeping new rules to protect the privacy of medical records. But under pressure from the health care industry, officials say, they are backing off a proposal to give patients a broad new right to sue and recover damages for the improper disclosure of confidential information. Chris Jennings, the health policy coordinator at the White House, said President Clinton would issue the final rules, with the force of law, in the next few weeks.

headline.main: Clinton to Issue New Rules On Medical Data Privacy

docs.abstract: Clinton administration will soon issue sweeping new rules to protect privacy of medical records, but it is reportedly backing off from proposal to give patients broad new right to sue and recover damages for improper disclosure of confidential information because of pressure from health care industry; Pres Clinton will issue final rules, having force of law, in next few weeks (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT has become an unspoken cultural axiom: anything less than financial well-being is a person's own fault. After all, this nation has been on a prosperity bender for the better part of a decade, intoxicated by the economy's seemingly boundless potential to generate fortunes or, at least, jobs. Certainly, there are sober moments when the plight of those bypassed or trapped by the boom pierces the collective conscience. Mostly, though, people in need seem to be a parenthetical phrase in the rosy rhetoric of sustained expansion.

headline.main: Behind the Prosperity, Working People in Trouble

docs.abstract: Article on working families who are turning to charities to make ends meet; charity officers explain hidden signs of poverty that persist even in bustling economy, especially in areas with high housing costs; photos; graph (special section, Giving) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: How about publishing a rebuttal written by someone who has to pay $15,600 a year out of pocket for drugs? It's easy to ''love drug companies'' when your insurance company pays for your prescriptions. By the way, your ''special advertising supplement'' in the same issue was a reminder of another reason why drug prices are so high: the cost of marketing drugs. Vicki Meagher Nashua, N.H.
docs.abstract: Vicki Meagher letter on high cost of drugs (Andrew Sullivan's Oct 29 article) cites high cost of marketing drugs; holds it is easy 'to love drug companies' when an insurance company is paying for one's drugs
docs.snippet: How about publishing a rebuttal written by someone who has to pay $15,600 a year out of pocket for drugs? It's easy to ''love drug companies'' when your insurance company pays for your prescriptions. By the way, your ''special advertising...

docs.lead_paragraph: Andrew Sullivan (The Way We Live Now, Oct. 29) totes up his own annual drug bill, paid ''mercifully'' by his insurance company, and cheerfully informs us that the amount is ''easily more than I pay separately for housing, food, travel or clothes.'' There's hope for those left out, however, if they will only be patient until ''patents run out and generics compete.'' Meanwhile, they can console themselves with the thought of better drugs, free, for Sullivan. ''Mercy,'' sad to say, has nothing to do with it. Daniel Hall Amherst, Mass.
docs.abstract: Daniel Hall letter on Andrew Sullivan's Oct 29 article on cost of prescription drugs
